properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locally heavy snow squalls this late afternoon into this evening. Locally heavy snow squalls will continue to develop and move across the area this evening. Locally heavy snow and reduced visibilities in blowing snow will make travel difficult at times. Up to 15 cm of new snowfall can be expected locally by the time the snow squalls move south of the area tonight. Travelers should consider changing their travel plans accordingly. Additional heavy flurries and snow squalls will be possible for areas generally west of a line from Midland to Orillia Friday and Friday night. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-22T12:00:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-21T20:07:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2893574029.2021
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and blowing snow are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm through Friday night, with additional amounts expected over the weekend. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h. Locations: southeastern Labrador from Lodge Bay to Rigolet. Time span: Friday through the weekend. Remarks: Snow will begin by Friday morning and will become heavy at times Friday night. The fresh snowfall will combine with moderate northeasterly winds to reduce visibilities in blowing snow beginning near midnight Friday night. There is currently some uncertainty as to when the storm will end, Poor travel conditions may persist through the weekend. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-22T11:47:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-21T19:48:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2202900659.2021
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls late this afternoon and this evening. Additional snow squalls Friday and Friday night. Locally heavy snow squalls have developed over Georgian Bay and will move across the area this evening. Locally heavy snow and reduced visibilities in blowing snow will make travel difficult at times. Travelers should consider changing their travel plans accordingly. Up to 15 cm of new snowfall will be possible under these snow squalls before they move south of the area tonight. After a brief lull tonight, additional local snow squalls are expected Friday and Friday night. Additional snowfall amounts from these squalls could exceed 30 cm by Saturday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for early this evening due to snow squalls. An initial band of snow squalls has moved south of the area. However, additional snow squalls developing over Georgian Bay may move into the area early this evening. Locally heavy snow and reduced visibilities in blowing snow will again be a concern early this evening. Up to 10 cm of new snowfall can be expected by the time the snow squalls end tonight. Travelers should consider changing their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected today. Conditions will improve by the end of the day. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and potential for blowing snow tonight to Saturday morning. Locations: the Great Northern Peninsula. Total possible snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Time span: Overnight tonight through to Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin overnight tonight and persist through Friday and Friday night. The bulk of the snow is expected Friday afternoon and Friday night. Moderate northwesterly winds will develop on Friday, occasionally reducing visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. Winds will shift to moderate southwesterlies on Friday night, causing another period of blowing snow over exposed areas. Conditions are expected to improve Saturday morning. At this time, there is a possibility that more snow and wind will develop again on Saturday night. This scenario is currently very uncertain and more details will be provided in subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-22T06:28:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-21T14:29:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1105508505.2021
Area: Northern Peninsula East, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 50 km/h. Locations: Port Saunders and the Straits, Northern Peninsula East. Time span: overnight until Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will begin over the Great Northern Peninsula overnight and continue until Saturday morning. Strong winds will develop on Friday evening causing reduced visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather expected tonight and Friday. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly near 80 km/h along the coast. Locations: the northeast coast from Clarenville to Green Bay - White Bay, excluding the Bonavista peninsula and Bonavista North. Time span: This evening into Friday afternoon. Remarks: A developing storm south of Nova Scotia will track east of Newfoundland today and Friday. Snow is expected to spread across the northeast coast this evening along with moderate winds, occasionally reducing visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. On Friday, winds will shift to northwesterly and intensify, especially along Notre Dame Bay and over Fogo Island. Wind and snow will combine to occasionally reduce visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. Conditions will improve by Friday afternoon. There is still uncertainty regarding snowfall amounts for Green Bay - White Bay. At this time, only 5 to 10 cm is forecast in the area. However, higher amounts are possible over northern portions of the Baie Verte Peninsula. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-22T00:45:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-21T08:46:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2061487846.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Locally heavy snow squalls this evening. Additional snow squalls likely Friday and Friday night. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to move across the area this evening. After a lull in the squall activity tonight, additional locally heavy snow squalls are expected Friday and Friday night for portions of the area. Up to 10 cm of new snowfall will be possible tonight. An additional local 15 cm will be possible Friday, with and additional 10 cm possible Friday night, particularly for areas closer to Lake Simcoe. Reduced visibilities in heavy snow and local blowing snow will make travel difficult at times during this period. Travelers should consider postponing or changing their travel plans accordingly. The snow squalls are forecast to come to an end on Saturday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly and northwesterly 80 km/h. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula and Bonavista North.
